instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.BKLT_SCL: What is BKLT_SCL? BKLT_SCL is an I2C signal clock line between the LED driver that creates the LCD backlight power rail that powers the backlight in the screen and the screen. The screen needs to speak to the LED driver on this line before backlight voltage will be created..
definitions.BKLT_SDA: What is BKLT_SDA? BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_PWM: What is EDP_BKLT_PWM? EDP_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.I2C_BKLT: What is I2C_BKLT? I2C_BKLT is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
no water damage, the mac was fall...
screen o.k replace cable also.
F8400 is good. <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is at 3.3V
<DIODE>D8410</DIODE> measurements are good.
1) 1.116
2) .800 
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>  5.1v
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> 5V.
all really look good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Do you get image on internal LCD, only missing backlight?
Be aware, dropped machine is a nightmare...

threads.message: i was put other board instead and it work fine and also work with external screen...only backlight! there is picture.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Please, stop to quote an entire post visible few centimeters above.

What about <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL>?
Tried PRAM reset?
Resolder all around <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> and check the traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> must be high.
But <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> is controlled through I2C bus from PCH, via LCD panel.
Check all <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>-52 resistors and traces.
Post voltage and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines.
Also check traces from J8500 for any BKLT signal.
Do you get any voltage at <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
"and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines."
???

Possibly bad contacts at J8500.
Did you check traces between <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>/51 and J8500 and <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
Because <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> MUST tie <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> to ground first.
And depends by <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT</SIGNAL> bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message: so to soldering j8500 and resoldering <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
You should check conectivity from J8500 to other components.
But this will not allow you to discard bad connections inside of J8500; with the small flex.
May need to check continuity from the other end of small cable, to the MLB components.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
I was check all the BKLT continuity and thay all fine(but I will do recheck), do I need to check all the J8500 connections?
I have other same good board so I check with it also..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight
threads.message:
changed <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> again and BOOM! backlight is back!
thanks!
